description: This course relies on a variety of sociological perspectives to examine the role of the media and popular culture in society, with a particular emphasis on the power of the entertainment industries, the relationship between cultural consumption and status, and the social organization of leisure activities from sports to shopping. Specific course topics include the globalization of branding and popular culture, the rise of aesthetics and style in everyday life, the importance of social networks in the diffusion of fads, fashions, and mass media; and the social effects of new media technologies in the digital age.
name: SOC. OF MEDIA & POP CULT

values.comments:
Sociology of Media and Pop Culture emphasizes the importance of the organization of the culture industries, the relationship between cultural consumption and status, and the social significance of leisure activities from sports to shopping. Specific course topics include the branding of Disney, Nike and Starbucks; the globalization of popular culture; the blurring of entertainment and politics; and the rise of new media technologies in the digital age.
  This course received “two thumbs up!” from all reviewers, many of whom recommended this class to others and consider it one of their favorites at Penn. Students found class interesting and activities creative; they were engaged in the course and enjoyed their time in it. One explained, “The class is about things we already know plenty about (pop culture) so discussion was lively and the readings were pertinent.”
  The overwhelmingly positive reviews for this course all focused on the professor. Professor Nolan received rave reviews for being both a fantastic instructor and for engaging her students. One student called her “perhaps the most humorous, engaging, amicable professor I have come across in my time at Penn” with the “rare ability to make material both accessible and enjoyable.” She is also praised for her accessibility; students say she is approachable, fair, and attuned to student interests.   
The course is heavy on readings and discussions. Though some students said readings are long and dense, they were satisfied with how Professor Nolan broke down the information and made it relevant. Student reviews did not focus on difficulty or type of assignments, but one noted that the course is broken into “easily digestible points that make studying easy.”
